title: How to Swap Hard Disk Drive Platters

steps.title: Know that this is only a last resort.
steps.content: Know that this is only a last resort. You have tried everything else, your data is not extremely important, and/or your cash flow restricts the use of a professional service.

steps.title: Set up a clean work environment.
steps.content: Set up a clean work environment. You can not make a super clean environment at home but use some common sense, and do the best you can. Keep air flow to a minimum.

steps.title: Ground yourself!
steps.content: Ground yourself! If you don't know what is, or how to do it, ask Google.

steps.title: Remove the cover of your dead drive.
steps.content: Remove the cover of your dead drive. If the cover doesn’t just lift off, look for more screws! There are screws under labels.

steps.title: Once the cover is off, inspect the platters.
steps.content: Once the cover is off, inspect the platters. If they are scratched, scorched, warped, or otherwise damaged, stop you are done!

steps.title: Set the cover back on - if the platters are physically damaged chances are you will not be able to recover any data.
steps.content: Set the cover back on - if the platters are physically damaged chances are you will not be able to recover any data. You can still try if you like.

steps.title: Purchase a new HDD with the same model number and firmware version.
steps.content: Purchase a new HDD with the same model number and firmware version.

steps.title: Test the new HDD.
steps.content: Test the new HDD. Make sure you can read and write data to and from it.

steps.title: Remove the cover from your donor HDD.
steps.content: Remove the cover from your donor HDD.

steps.title: Remove the platters from the donor HDD.
steps.content: Remove the platters from the donor HDD. This is your chance to learn how they are assembled, if you slip and damage parts you can get a new donor. NOTE: if you are dealing with multiple platters they cannot be removed without the proper equipment, because misalignment of the platters will destroy any chance of recovering data. You need a platter removal tool. The next steps are only if you are dealing with a single platter.

steps.title: Remove the platter from your dead HDD.
steps.content: Remove the platter from your dead HDD.

steps.title: Reassemble the donor drive with dead HDD’s platters inside (make sure all the platters are aligned in the same way towards each other as they were in the old drive).
steps.content: Reassemble the donor drive with dead HDD’s platters inside (make sure all the platters are aligned in the same way towards each other as they were in the old drive).

steps.title: Quickly copy your data.
steps.content: Quickly copy your data. You might only get one or two chances to read from the HDD. It might make some horrible noises.

steps.title: Unmount the HDD and discard it.
steps.content: Unmount the HDD and discard it. Continued use of the HDD is ill-advised.
